cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
who is the all time leading scorer in ncaa tournament history
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
To determine the all-time leading scorer in NCAA tournament history, we need to consider the statistics from NCAA basketball tournaments, specifically focusing on individual player scoring records. This information is typically compiled from various sources, including NCAA records and sports statistics databases. 

As of my last update, the player who holds the record for the most points scored in NCAA tournament history is Christian Laettner. He played for Duke University from 1988 to 1992 and is known for his exceptional performance during the NCAA tournaments, particularly in 1992 when he led Duke to a national championship.

To confirm this, we can check the latest statistics and records from reliable sports news sources or the NCAA's official records. However, based on the information available up to October 2023, Laettner remains the leading scorer.

Answer:
Christian Laettner is the all-time leading scorer in NCAA tournament history.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who is the all time leading scorer in ncaa tournament history
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
["In 2008, Duke's Matt Danowski surpassed Vasta as the all-time leading scorer. Along with Danowski, Vasta is one of only six NCAA players to reach the 150-150 plateau (goals and assists).\n", 'Three players\xa0– Bira Maciel and Marcel De Souza of Brazil and Phil Smyth of Australia\xa0– have appeared in five tournaments. Six different players have won medals in four tournaments. Brazilian legend Oscar Schmidt is the runaway all-time leading scorer, scoring 843 career points in four tournaments, between 1978 and 1990. Nikos Galis of Greece, is the all-time leading scorer for a single tournament, averaging 33.7 points per game for the Greeks at the 1986 FIBA World Championship.\n', '1947 kicks off the "golden age" of NAIA National Tournaments. Harold Haskins became the first of 16 all-time leading scorers. \n', 'BULLET::::- February 25, 2011: Meghan Agosta scored her 151st career goal to become all-time leading goal scorer in NCAA history. She accomplished this in a 6-2 victory over the Robert Morris Colonials women’s ice hockey program at the Mercyhurst Ice Center.\n', 'Compilations of collegiate records by the NCAA, continuing into 2006, have ignored or segregated the contributions of AIAW athletes. Major college basketball\'s career women\'s scoring leader, Lynette Woodard of the University of Kansas, speaking on the exclusion of AIAW statistics, said, "Basketball doesn\'t just start with when the NCAA blessed it. And it\'s not about Jackie [Stiles, NCAA career scoring leader] and it\'s not about Lynette. It\'s about history. History is history."\n', "BULLET::::- On December 18, Tyler Hansbrough passed Phil Ford to become North Carolina's all-time leading scorer. On February 28, Hansbrough also broke Dickie Hemric's NCAA record for most free throws made in a career. And on March 19, Hansbrough passed J. J. Redick as the leading scorer in Atlantic Coast Conference history.\n", "Gray was suspended in the first game of his senior season due to playing in a church league after his friend paid the $5 admission fee. Gray became the American Athletic Conference's all-time scoring leader on February 11 in a 73–42 victory over Tulane, breaking the record set by Nic Moore. In the AAC Tournament, he scored 33 points in a 77–74 victory over Wichita State. Gray hit the game-winning layup with 1.1 seconds to go to beat San Diego State 67–65 in the first round of the NCAA Tournament. He finished with a career-high 39 points. He scored a conference-leading 19.3 points per game and dished out 4.4 assists per game as a senior. Gray was named to the First Team All-AAC for the second straight year.\n", "NCAA Division I Men's Golf Tournament all-time individual records\n", "NCAA Division I Men's Golf Tournament all-time team records\n", "Goalie Julian Baretta was chosen as the Most Outstanding Player in the NCAA Tournament. He had two shutouts and a .905 save percentage for the season. The team's leading scorer was junior defenseman Craig Norwich with 18 goals, 65 assists, and 83 points. Norwich was the second defenseman (Dan Lodboa, 1970) in NCAA history to lead his team in scoring while winning a National Title in the same season (the next occurrence was 2018).\n"]

2. **Oscar Schmidt**:
   - "Brazilian legend Oscar Schmidt is the runaway all-time leading scorer, scoring 843 career points in four tournaments, between 1978 and 1990."
   - **Role**: Although this refers to international basketball tournaments rather than NCAA tournaments, it emphasizes the importance of scoring records in sports and the potential for athletes to achieve significant milestones. It also illustrates that scoring records can be context-dependent, varying by tournament and sport.

3. **Lynette Woodard and Jackie Stiles**:
   - "Major college basketball's career women's scoring leader, Lynette Woodard of the University of Kansas... it's not about Jackie [Stiles, NCAA career scoring leader]... it's about history."

It underscores the complexity of defining "all-time leading scorers" and the importance of historical context in sports records.

It also illustrates the competitive nature of scoring records within specific programs.

To directly answer the question, the all-time leading scorer in NCAA tournament history is **Kareem Abdul-Jabbar**, who scored 564 points during his time at UCLA from 1966 to 1969. This information is not present in the provided passages but is essential for fully addressing the question.

Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To determine the all-time leading scorer in NCAA tournament history, we need to focus specifically on NCAA basketball statistics, as the question pertains to individual player scoring records within the NCAA tournaments. 

1. **Understanding NCAA Tournament Context**: The NCAA tournament, also known as "March Madness," is a single-elimination tournament held annually to determine the national champion of men's and women's college basketball in the United States. The scoring records from this tournament are distinct from regular season records and other collegiate sports.

2. **Historical Context**: The all-time leading scorer in NCAA tournament history is often a point of pride for players and schools, as it reflects not only individual talent but also the ability to perform under pressure in high-stakes games. This context is important because it highlights the significance of the achievement.

3. **Key Players**: While Christian Laettner is frequently mentioned as a prominent figure in NCAA tournament history due to his performance with Duke University, it is essential to verify the current record holder. Historically, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar (then known as Lew Alcindor) holds the record for the most points scored in NCAA tournament history, with 564 points during his time at UCLA from 1966 to 1969.

4. **Verification of Current Records**: To ensure accuracy, it's important to reference reliable sports statistics databases or the NCAA's official records. As of the latest updates, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar remains the all-time leading scorer in NCAA tournament history, surpassing other notable players.

5. **Comparative Analysis**: The passages provided earlier discuss various scoring records across different sports and contexts, emphasizing the competitive nature of scoring achievements. This highlights that while Laettner is a significant figure, the historical record belongs to Abdul-Jabbar, showcasing the importance of context in understanding scoring milestones.

### Answer:
Kareem Abdul-Jabbar is the all-time leading scorer in NCAA tournament history, with 564 points scored during his time at UCLA from 1966 to 1969.

["In 2008, Duke's Matt Danowski surpassed Vasta as the all-time leading scorer. Along with Danowski, Vasta is one of only six NCAA players to reach the 150-150 plateau (goals and assists).\n", 'Three players\xa0– Bira Maciel and Marcel De Souza of Brazil and Phil Smyth of Australia\xa0– have appeared in five tournaments. Six different players have won medals in four tournaments. Brazilian legend Oscar Schmidt is the runaway all-time leading scorer, scoring 843 career points in four tournaments, between 1978 and 1990. Nikos Galis of Greece, is the all-time leading scorer for a single tournament, averaging 33.7 points per game for the Greeks at the 1986 FIBA World Championship.\n', '1947 kicks off the "golden age" of NAIA National Tournaments. Harold Haskins became the first of 16 all-time leading scorers. \n', 'BULLET::::- February 25, 2011: Meghan Agosta scored her 151st career goal to become all-time leading goal scorer in NCAA history. She accomplished this in a 6-2 victory over the Robert Morris Colonials women’s ice hockey program at the Mercyhurst Ice Center.\n', 'Compilations of collegiate records by the NCAA, continuing into 2006, have ignored or segregated the contributions of AIAW athletes. And it\'s not about Jackie [Stiles, NCAA career scoring leader] and it\'s not about Lynette. It\'s about history. Redick as the leading scorer in Atlantic Coast Conference history.\n", "Gray was suspended in the first game of his senior season due to playing in a church league after his friend paid the $5 admission fee. Gray became the American Athletic Conference's all-time scoring leader on February 11 in a 73–42 victory over Tulane, breaking the record set by Nic Moore. In the AAC Tournament, he scored 33 points in a 77–74 victory over Wichita State. Gray hit the game-winning layup with 1.1 seconds to go to beat San Diego State 67–65 in the first round of the NCAA Tournament. He finished with a career-high 39 points. He scored a conference-leading 19.3 points per game and dished out 4.4 assists per game as a senior. Gray was named to the First Team All-AAC for the second straight year.\n", "NCAA Division I Men's Golf Tournament all-time individual records\n", "NCAA Division I Men's Golf Tournament all-time team records\n", "Goalie Julian Baretta was chosen as the Most Outstanding Player in the NCAA Tournament. He had two shutouts and a .905 save percentage for the season. The team's leading scorer was junior defenseman Craig Norwich with 18 goals, 65 assists, and 83 points. Norwich was the second defenseman (Dan Lodboa, 1970) in NCAA history to lead his team in scoring while winning a National Title in the same season (the next occurrence was 2018).\n"]

question_info.question: who is the all time leading scorer in ncaa tournament history
passages:
In 2008, Duke's Matt Danowski surpassed Vasta as the all-time leading scorer. Along with Danowski, Vasta is one of only six NCAA players to reach the 150-150 plateau (goals and assists).
Three players – Bira Maciel and Marcel De Souza of Brazil and Phil Smyth of Australia – have appeared in five tournaments. Six different players have won medals in four tournaments. Brazilian legend Oscar Schmidt is the runaway all-time leading scorer, scoring 843 career points in four tournaments, between 1978 and 1990. Nikos Galis of Greece, is the all-time leading scorer for a single tournament, averaging 33.7 points per game for the Greeks at the 1986 FIBA World Championship.
1947 kicks off the "golden age" of NAIA National Tournaments. Harold Haskins became the first of 16 all-time leading scorers. 
BULLET::::- February 25, 2011: Meghan Agosta scored her 151st career goal to become all-time leading goal scorer in NCAA history. She accomplished this in a 6-2 victory over the Robert Morris Colonials women’s ice hockey program at the Mercyhurst Ice Center.
Compilations of collegiate records by the NCAA, continuing into 2006, have ignored or segregated the contributions of AIAW athletes. Major college basketball's career women's scoring leader, Lynette Woodard of the University of Kansas, speaking on the exclusion of AIAW statistics, said, "Basketball doesn't just start with when the NCAA blessed it. And it's not about Jackie [Stiles, NCAA career scoring leader] and it's not about Lynette. It's about history. History is history."
BULLET::::- On December 18, Tyler Hansbrough passed Phil Ford to become North Carolina's all-time leading scorer. On February 28, Hansbrough also broke Dickie Hemric's NCAA record for most free throws made in a career. And on March 19, Hansbrough passed J. J. Redick as the leading scorer in Atlantic Coast Conference history.
Gray was suspended in the first game of his senior season due to playing in a church league after his friend paid the $5 admission fee. Gray became the American Athletic Conference's all-time scoring leader on February 11 in a 73–42 victory over Tulane, breaking the record set by Nic Moore. In the AAC Tournament, he scored 33 points in a 77–74 victory over Wichita State. Gray hit the game-winning layup with 1.1 seconds to go to beat San Diego State 67–65 in the first round of the NCAA Tournament. He finished with a career-high 39 points. He scored a conference-leading 19.3 points per game and dished out 4.4 assists per game as a senior. Gray was named to the First Team All-AAC for the second straight year.
NCAA Division I Men's Golf Tournament all-time individual records
NCAA Division I Men's Golf Tournament all-time team records
Goalie Julian Baretta was chosen as the Most Outstanding Player in the NCAA Tournament. He had two shutouts and a .905 save percentage for the season. The team's leading scorer was junior defenseman Craig Norwich with 18 goals, 65 assists, and 83 points. Norwich was the second defenseman (Dan Lodboa, 1970) in NCAA history to lead his team in scoring while winning a National Title in the same season (the next occurrence was 2018).
